answers.answer: Hi,I suggest that you have a complete assessment done. You may need to have your blood sugar levels and thyroid hormone levels determined. A urinalysis and urine culture will help rule out an underlying infection or the possible presence of stones.Are your symptoms associated with a sense of urgency?Urodynamic studies may also be necessary . Differentials for your case is a urinary tract infection, an urge incontinence, polyuria due to an underlying systemic disease like diabetes, and interstitial cystitis.These are just differentials and further tests are necessary to ascertain the diagnosis.

question: I'm a 37 yr old female in good health.  Over the past 1 year or so I've had to get up during the night more & more to urinate.  I'm at a point now where it's every hour.   I have no pain, burning, etc.  When I urinate it's a small amount and very diluted.  It wakes me up from a dead sleep; no incontinence.  During the day I'm very normal; I urinate larger concentrated amounts that are directly related to what I've recently had to drink.    I only have caffeine in the morning, rarely alchohol, no stress.   I'm at a loss, any ideas?    I've had a complete recent physical-no issues & been to the urologist-no issues.  He gave me Vesicare to try out for overactive bladder but it only seems to help slightly.Help; I need sleep!
title: Frequent urination at night
